CHLORPROMAZINE HYDROCHLORIDE

ANTIPSYCHOTIC DRUGS

  • Pregnancy

  • Renal impairment

  • Side effects

  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Schizophrenia and other psychoses, Mania, Short-term adjunctive management of severe anxiety, Psychomotor agitation, excitement, and violent or dangerously impulsive behaviour,

By rectum

  • For adults
    Initially 25 mg 3 times a day, adjusted according to response, alternatively initially 75 mg once daily, adjusted according to response, dose to be taken at night; maintenance 75–300 mg daily, increased if necessary up to 1 g daily, this dose may be required in psychoses, take a third to half adult dose in the elderly and debilitated patients.
  • For adults
    100 mg every 6–8 hours, dose expressed as chlorpromazine base.

Intractable hiccup,

By mouth

  • For adults
    25–50 mg 3–4 times a day.

Relief of acute symptoms of psychoses (under expert supervision),

By deep intramuscular injection

  • For adults
    25–50 mg every 6–8 hours.

Nausea and vomiting of terminal illness (where other drugs have failed or are not available),

By rectum

  • For adults
    10–25 mg every 4–6 hours.
  • For adults
    Initially 25 mg, then 25–50 mg every 3–4 hours until vomiting stops.
  • For adults
    100 mg every 6–8 hours.
  • For children 1–5 years
    500 micrograms/kg every 4–6 hours; maximum 40 mg per day.
  • For children 6–11 years
    500 micrograms/kg every 4–6 hours; maximum 75 mg per day.
  • For children 12–17 years
    10–25 mg every 4–6 hours.
  • For children 1–5 years
    500 micrograms/kg every 6–8 hours; maximum 40 mg per day.
  • For children 6–11 years
    500 micrograms/kg every 6–8 hours; maximum 75 mg per day.
  • For children 12–17 years
    Initially 25 mg, then 25–50 mg every 3–4 hours until vomiting stops.

Dose adjustments due to interactions

Dose adjustment may be necessary if smoking started or stopped during treatment.

Dose equivalence and conversion

For equivalent therapeutic effect 100 mg chlorpromazine base given rectally as a suppository ≡ 20–25 mg chlorpromazine hydrochloride by intramuscular injection ≡ 40–50 mg of chlorpromazine base or hydrochloride given by mouth.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Extrapyramidal effects and withdrawal syndrome have been reported occasionally in the neonate when antipsychotic drugs are taken during the third trimester of pregnancy.

Following maternal use of antipsychotic drugs in the third trimester, neonates should be monitored for symptoms including agitation, hypertonia, hypotonia, tremor, drowsiness, feeding problems, and respiratory distress.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

Can precipitate coma; phenothiazines are hepatotoxic.

Advice regarding renal impairment

Start with small doses in severe renal impairment because of increased cerebral sensitivity.

Contra indications

  • CNS depression
  • comatose states
  • hypothyroidism
  • phaeochromocytoma

Known side effects

When used for Nausea and vertigo

Acute dystonic reactions

Phenothiazines can induce acute dystonic reactions such as facial and skeletal muscle spasms and oculogyric crises; children (especially girls, young women, and those under 10 kg) are particularly susceptible.

Cautions regarding administration

  • Diabetes

Monitoring requirements

Patient parameters

With intramuscular use

Patients should remain supine, with blood pressure monitoring for 30 minutes after intramuscular injection.

Unlicensed use

Rectal route is not licensed.

Advice regarding handling and storage

Owing to the risk of contact sensitisation, pharmacists, nurses, and other health workers should avoid direct contact with chlorpromazine; tablets should not be crushed and solutions should be handled with care.

Prepared medicinal forms of CHLORPROMAZINE HYDROCHLORIDE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: suppository, oral suspension, oral solution, capsule,
Tablet
Oral solution
Solution for injection
